Hi Chong,

of course! Using the notation from Lipton, Berkowitz, and Elkan:

  1. Let's suppose h^(t-1) is size [m]
  2. W^(gh) will be the size of [n, m] so the g^t will be the size of [n] -- same story for i^t, f^t, and o^t.
  3. Both s^(t-1) and s^t will be the size of [n]
  4. h^t will be the size of [n]

The other params:

  1. All b params will be size of [n]
  2. All input matrices W^(_x) will be size of [n, input_features_size]
  3. x^(t) will be size of [input_features_size]

Does it make sense to you?

of course! Using the notation from [Lipton, Berkowitz, and Elkan](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1506.00019.pdf):

0. Let's suppose **h^(t-1) is size [m]**
1. W^(gh) will be the size of [n, m] so the g^t will be the size of [n] -- same story for i^t, f^t, and o^t.
2. Both s^(t-1) and s^t will be the size of [n]
3. **h^t will be the size of [n]**

The other params:

4) All b params will be size of [n]
5) All input matrices W^(_x) will be size of [n, input_features_size]

Does it make sense to you?
